title: Scarlett Moffatt defends bringing house to British Tribe Next Door
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Scarlett Moffatt has defended her family home being recreated in Namibia for her controversial Channel 4 series British Tribe Next Door.

The former Gogglebox star explained to Ruth Langsford and Eamonn Holmes on This Morning that the local tribe wouldn’t have been able get a real glimpse of her life in the UK if the makeshift replica hadn’t been built.

Ruth told her: ‘There could be people who would say could have just gone to live with the Himba people in their mud huts, so what was the premise of taking the house?’

Advertisement

‘Then they wouldn’t have seen how we live,’ Scarlett replied.

She then revealed that her ‘best friend’ on the series got to get a real look into her life, saying: ‘She was like, “Why have you got so many things? Why have you got so much stuff?”‘

Scarlett admitted she thought the Himba people would be a fan of her family’s digs, which had running water, WiFi and a washing machine, but they wanted it to be taken down.

British Tribe Next Door airs tonight (Picture: Channel 4)

‘It’s such a sense of community there, going to get wood and cleaning, everything’s done as a family and as a whole, whereas they found us very isolated,’ she said.

‘It’s really changed our outlook. I thought we spent loads of time together, but being there made me realise that we don’t and we could spend more time together.’

Many were angered at the news of Scarlett’s series when it was first commissioned with some branding it ‘racist’.

‘I’ve just found out that Scarlett Moffatt has an incredibly racist new series coming out called The British Tribe Next Door where they move her whole family to Africa in a house. You can’t make this up,’ one complained.

Meanwhile, another wrote: ‘I’d love to know why you thought this would be a good idea? The whole concept is inherently racist and taking western privilege to a tribe in Africa, simply for the sake of TV is embarrassing.’

Alf Lawrie, Channel 4’s head of factual entertainment, previously said of the show’s commission: ‘For the first time in human history, British suburbia and Himba tribal life will coexist side-by-side.

‘This series contrasts two worlds on a spectacular scale – but at its heart, is about the extraordinary relationships it creates.

‘Scarlett and the Himba are the perfect foils, both hospitable, curious, friendly… and sharing wicked sense of humour.’

This Morning airs weekdays at 10.30am on ITV.
